oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Claims for property taken pamphlet
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; Tennessee -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; Forage; United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865 -- Claims; War damage compensation
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Pamphlet issued by J. L. MacFarland, Solicitor of Claims, instructing individuals on how to recover claims with the United States for personal property used in the war effort by the U. S. Army. Loyalty requirements are listed, as are the types of property eligible and instructions on how to prepare and submit claims.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: McFarland, J. L.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The U. S. Army relied heavily on impressed goods while on campaign. While the Quartermaster furnished rations and other goods for the army, many items, such as horses, mules, wood, and animal feed, were often taken from the local population. The U. S. government promised to reimburse individuals for impressed items through January 1, 1880, after which no further claims would be accepted.
